newsitem.title: USA: Poland finmin asks for patience on domestic demand.
newsitem.headline: Poland finmin asks for patience on domestic demand.

text.p: Poland's Finance Minister Marek Belka asked on Monday for patience to allow monetary and fiscal measures to bring down the country's current account deficit and burgeoning domestic demand.
The minister rejected any suggestion that Poland might accelerate the pace of its currency devaluation to address the demand imbalance.
"Our economic policy is oriented toward slowing down the growth of domestic demand," Belka told U.S. investors gathered here at a road show for Poland's inaugural yankee bond.
The minister said the National Bank of Poland had raised interest rates to dampen domestic demand, but that these measures needed time to achieve the desired effect.
"You should have some faith in monetary policy and some patience," Belka said.
Last week, National Bank of Poland president Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz said the central bank might raise interest rates further if excessive credit growth continued.
Last week, the central bank reported that the current account deficit grew to $2.27 billion in the first four months of 1997 from a $226 million gap for the same period last year.
Belka said that Poland's current account deficit had stabilized on a quarter-by-quarter basis, but that Poland had concentrated both fiscal and monetary policy toward its deceleration.
"We clearly are concerned, even if we think that this year there is no danger at all," Belka said. "If it's left complacently, it can explode."
The government would not speed up the pace of its program of currency devaluation, which decreases the zloty at one percentage point per month, Belka said.
"We are not considering a faster devaluation, on the contrary we are aware this rate of devaluation is probably excessive," Belka said.
Given that inflation had dropped to 0.4-0.6 pct per month, the government could reduce its zloty devaluation rate but held off because of the growth of demand, he said.
"Because of our concerns about the current account deficit, we are still keeping the 1.0 percent a month devaluation even if it may slows down the disinflation process," Belka said.
Belka also said next year's budget would be much more restrictive to address the demand problem.
Poland's economic team had travelled to New York to present its upcoming yankee bond to U.S. investors, a $300 million seven year issue via JP Morgan that is expected to price this week.

Wieslaw Szczuka, director of the foreign department of Poland's Finance Ministry, said the yankee issue could grow as high as $400 million, depending on market conditions. He added the government would seek approval from Congress to issue some $500 million in foreign bond issuance in 1998.
"We will continue the policy of being very modest in bond borrowing in foreign markets," Szczuka said. "There is no need to borrow heavily."
